metaDescription: Calculate 1099 vs W2 contractor net pay in the USA including tax deductions.
primaryKeyword: USA Contractor Calculator, Contractor Salary USA
intro: Calculate your contractor salary in the USA with our comprehensive calculator designed specifically for contractors and freelancers. US contractors have unique tax obligations including self-employment tax (15.3%) instead of FICA taxes, plus federal and state income taxes. This calculator uses official 2026 IRS rates to compare take-home pay for 1099 contractors vs W-2 employees, helping you choose the most tax-efficient structure for your contracting work. Whether you're considering contracting for the first time, comparing offers from different clients, or optimizing your current setup, this tool provides accurate calculations for US contractors and freelancers.
howThisCalculatorWorks: This USA contractor salary calculator determines take-home pay for self-employed contractors by applying self-employment tax (15.3% instead of FICA), federal income tax, state income tax, and accounting for business expenses and quarterly estimated tax payments. Contractors typically work as 1099 independent contractors rather than W-2 employees, facing different tax treatments. The calculator shows your net income after all federal, state, and self-employment taxes, helping you understand the true cost of self-employment in the US.

example1.title: $500/day Contractor
example1.scenario: Software developer working $500 per day, 20 days per month as 1099 contractor in California

example2.title: $650/day with Expenses
example2.scenario: $650 per day consultant, 15 days per month with $200/day business expenses in New York

example3.title: $600/day with 401k
example3.scenario: $600 per day freelancer, 18 days per month with $150/day expenses and self-employed 401(k) in Texas

whoShouldUseThisCalculator: Contractors comparing 1099 vs W-2 employment structures

contractorStructures.title: US Contractor Structures
structures: **1099 Contractor:** Self-employed, pays self-employment tax (15.3%) instead of FICA, files Schedule C, makes quarterly estimated payments
**W-2 Employee:** Employer withholds FICA taxes (7.65%), employer pays matching FICA, taxes withheld from paychecks
**LLC Owner:** Can elect corporate taxation or pass-through, provides some liability protection
**S-Corp Shareholder:** Allows reasonable salary + distributions, complex tax treatment

faqs.question: What's the difference between self-employment tax and FICA?
faqs.answer: Self-employment tax (15.3%) covers both the employee and employer portions of Social Security and Medicare taxes that W-2 employees split. Self-employed individuals pay the full amount.

faqs.question: How do contractors pay taxes in the USA?
faqs.answer: 1099 contractors make quarterly estimated tax payments (Form 1040-ES) for federal income tax and self-employment tax. State taxes vary by state. Many states require quarterly payments for state income tax.

faqs.question: Can contractors deduct business expenses?
faqs.answer: Yes, legitimate business expenses like home office, equipment, software, mileage, and professional services can be deducted, reducing taxable income and self-employment tax.

faqs.question: What's the tax rate for US contractors?
faqs.answer: Federal income tax rates (10-37%) plus self-employment tax (15.3%) plus state income tax (0-13.3%). Effective rates often range from 30-45% depending on income level and state.

faqs.question: Do contractors get retirement benefits?
faqs.answer: Contractors can set up SEP-IRA or Solo 401(k) plans with higher contribution limits than employee 401(k)s. They can also contribute to traditional or Roth IRAs.

conclusion: Choosing contractor status in the USA involves understanding complex tax obligations including self-employment tax, federal and state income taxes, and quarterly estimated payments. This calculator uses official 2026 IRS rates to help you understand the true cost of self-employment. Whether you're considering contracting for the first time or optimizing your current setup, understanding the tax implications is crucial. Remember that self-employment offers flexibility but comes with higher tax burdens and administrative responsibilities. For personalized advice, consult IRS resources or a qualified tax professional specializing in self-employment taxation.
disclaimer: SalaryWise provides estimated contractor calculations based on publicly available tax structures. Self-employment tax rules can be complex and may involve additional considerations. Results are for guidance only and should not be considered financial advice. Always consult official government resources or a qualified tax professional for personalized advice.
